text: FLYING OVER England, the green rolling Chiltern hills, ov woodland and villages and country houses. The CAMERA FINDS a handsome manor house. In the field by house, a cricket match is in full swing. EXT. CRICKET FIELD -— DAY 2 MOVING POV - A blur of tree trunks. Railings round a pavilion terrace. Glimpses of women drinking tea on a sun English afternoon. Sounds of a cricket match in progress. The UNKNOWN WATCHER is on the move, trying for a better vantage point. Now at last he catches a clear sighting of DIANA, a beautiful young woman, 22 years old, dark hair, calm manner. She’s seated on the pavilion terrace, surrounded by others but looking as if she’s alone. A you man, TOMMY, is clearly trying to talk to her, one hand nervously fiddling with his straw hat as he does so. Dian seems unaware of his existence. Some other figure crosses the line of vision, obscuring her. The MOVING POV shifts again. This time the watcher gets an even better view of her.
Dear God. What - is - that? ON ROBIN CAVENDISH, staring. A good-looking 25-year-old, dressed in cricketing whites, wearing pads. With him, als in whites, his friend COLIN CAMPBELL.
Not a chance.
(gazing at Diana) How so?
She’s a famous heart-breaker.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 2.
Do you know her?

I know her brothers. A glance towards two young men watching the cricket, identical twins BLOGGS and DAVID BLACKER. They too are watching Diana, amused by Tommy’s utter failure to attrac Diana’s attention. They’re mimicking the way his hand fid with his hat. Robin’s gaze turns from the twins back to Diana. The soun of a wicket being taken, and the clapping of the spectators.
She’s gorgeous.
No one’s ever got near. Martin proposed twice.
Would you marry Martin? I wouldn't. But I would marry me.
And I’m sure you'd be very happy together, Robin.
The thing is, I’m running out of time. I leave for Nairobi on July 15th. I need a wife. It’s now his turn to bat. Smiling, confident, he strides to the crease.

Robin prepares to face the bowler. He glances back at Dia on the pavilion terrace: he’s going to make her notice hi But Diana’s only half-watching. She’s bored. Tommy has given up. The ball hurtles towards Robin. He steps forward, smashes the ball with a sweeping off-drive. It sails over the pavilion for a glorious six. A cheer goes up. Diana is chatting to a girlfriend. She didn’t even notice Robin’s triumph.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 3.

Robin with a cup of tea in his hand moving past team mate and supporters, accepting congratulations as he goes. He’ heading for Diana. She sits staring far away at nothing. Still bored. He comes to a stop beside her. She doesn’t register his presence. He drinks his tea, watches her.
I know you can see me. Diana turns her lazy gaze to take him in.
I’m sorry?
I don’t believe you're half as bored as you look.
Do I look bored? I don’t mean to.
Cricket’s a lot more fun to play than to watch.
Yes. I suppose it is.
Like life, you might say.
Might you? An older friend, HARRY TENNYSON, comes up to Diana. Harry very overweight, and just walking gets him out of breath.
We're off. If you want a lift it’s now or never. Diana gets up.
I’m ready.
Will you be at the Barings’ bash on Saturday?
I might be.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 4.
Maybe see you there.
Maybe. She goes off with Harry. Robin watches her go, but she doesn’t give a backward glance.

MOVING POV - Through the throng of guests at the ball: glimpses of Diana, stunning in a formal gown. On her love face the same air of not seeing the bustle round her; of living in some other private world. Robin, smart in his formal evening clothes, tracks her wi his eyes. He moves steadily towards her. She turns, catch his gaze. Holds the look for a moment, then turns away. He reaches her. She shows no sign of noticing him.
I could ask you to dance. You could say you don’t feel like dancing right now. I could say, Next time, maybe. And I could saunter away.
You could saunter away.

Or I could just not ask. That’s unexpected. She looks at him, unsure what he means He takes her hand and pulls her onto the dance floor. She’s too taken by surprise to resist. Before she knows what’s happening they’re dancing. He dances very well. She lets him lead her, looking at hi with an amused quizzical look. She likes dancing with him
Robin’s battered old sports car bowls along an empty country road. Diana sits beside Robin. IN CAR -—  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 5.
So where are we going?

I thought Maidenhead. I know a rather jolly pub by the river. The car turns off into a lane that winds up a hill betwee trees, to come to a stop facing a giant vista of rolling countryside. Robin's favourite view.
This doesn’t look like a jolly pub by the river.
No. We seem to have missed our way.
What a surprise.
Lucky I packed a bottle of wine and a pork pie.
Good Lord, is that the time? She reaches for the car door handle. There is no car door handle.
How do you open the door?
You don’t.
But I want to get out.
No you don’t.
Don’t I?
You want to kiss me.

What makes you think I want to - He pulls her towards him and kisses her. No aggression, b nor does he give her any choice in the matter.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 6. For a moment she accepts the kiss passively. Then she starts to kiss him back. Then she starts to kiss him with real passion.

The grounds of Diana’s family home. Diana sits on a swing attached to a branch of a tree. She’s slowly twisting her round and round, winding the two ropes above her. At her on the grass lie her brothers, Bloggs and David.
(to Diana) You hardly know the little man.
(to Bloggs) Would you say he’s littler than us? The two brothers eye each other, as if making the mental comparison.
Not much in it.
(to Diana) Has he got any money at all?
It’s not like you don’t have other options.
What happened to Hugh? Doesn’t he have a castle in Scotland?
Mind you, who'd want to live in Scotland?
She's talking about going to live in Kenya, for God’s sake!
Diana, please stop going round and round and concentrate. This is your future life we’re talking about.
Your future happiness. Diana stops twirling. Her feet on the ground hold the swi steady.
9c 10 11 Breathe - Tan Revision - 2 August 2016 7.
The thing is, I just know this is it. She lifts her feet and the swing spins her round and roun skirts flying, as the ropes unwind.

We find ourselves flying through a magnificent gorge ravi The searing heat of the bright African light upon us. We over trees and waterfalls, ahead of us a towering mountai Into frame drops a Tiger Moth biplane, flying away from u Its pilot unknown.

The biplane, now a tiny speck, flies along a massive clif wall and circles over the planes below. EXT. KENYA 9c The biplane comes in to land. As it taxis and stops, the engines cut. The pilot climbs out of the cockpit, raising goggles, revealing that it is in fact ROBIN. He helps DIA down.

TRACKING PAST red earth, fields of sugar cane, banana groves. A Landrover jolts down the dusty road. In the Landrover Robin and Diana sit side by side, bronzed and beautiful. NOW TRACKING PAST thick bush - the view from the Landrove it heads into deep country - The sound of CRASHING in the trees - An ELEPHANT lumbers out into the track just ahead, frighteningly close. The MOVING POV screeches to a halt. elephant continues across the track, followed by another, another. In the Landrover Diana sits very still, captivated by the sight. Robin has his camera out, taking photographs. The of elephants passes in front of and behind their vehicles thrillingly close.
12 13 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016
12 13  14 Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 9.

Robin and Diana are out walking in the bush with their friends COLIN CAMPBELL, Dr DON MCQUEEN, MARY DAWNAY and KATHERINE BARING, all young people of their own age. They're on the lookout for wild animals. Both Robin and C carry guns. The women walk behind. Robin is entranced by immense view.
What is it you actually do out here, Robin?
I’m a tea broker. I get tea and I broke it. It’s very skilled work.
And what does Diana do while you're off broking?
She comes too.
My God! That’s almost indecent.
I like it. Really.
God gave men jobs to do so women could get a little time to themselves.
I like being with Robin. He's really quite bearable.
I can’t see it myself. It’s alla mystery to me.
What Colin means is, how on earth did Robin manage to nab Diana?
Oh we’d all like to know that.
I don’t know. How did you, darling?
It’s very simple, really. Diana is bone idle. She hates having to make decisions. (MORE )
Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 9aA.
She has no idea what she thinks about anything. So I tell her what to think, and I make all the decisions, and she’s happy as Larry. Right, darling?
If you say so.  Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 9A-9B.

Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 10. 14¢ EXT. NGONG HILLS, KENYA - EVENING 14c¢ The young people are gathered round a campfire in a grove fever trees, sharing a picnic supper. Diana lies with her head on Robin’s lap. Robin holds up his hand to ask for silence. Nothing but the sounds of dusk.
You hear that?
What? I don’t hear a thing.
That's just it. It’s like the dawn of creation.
The dusk of creation, you mean.
Watch out, Robin. Africa does funny things to people. (To Diana) Has he started talking to God?
Not exactly talking. But Robin and God are quite chummy.
You need faith to survive out here.
How can you say that, Don? And you a doctor.

Oh, I believe in the power of the mind. Did you hear about the African prisoners on Kome Island? During the Mau-Mau rebellion? There were sixty of them crammed into a small tin hut. Prison officer wouldn’t let them out. The Mau-Mau leader said, very well, I give my men permission to die. Next morning all sixty were dead.
How?
Mind power. They chose to die. Turned their faces to the wall and died.  Breathe - Salmon Revision - 26 July 2016 10A.
What a waste of mind power. I'd have chosen to live.
Quite right. Thats a sensible woman you've got there, Robin. Don’t lose her.
I’ll try not to. He bends down and kisses her.  15
Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 11.

The shady office of a tea warehouse. Drying tea plants ha over the windows, filtering the bright light. Diana sits fanning herself with a sales document at one end. Robin is inspecting the tea with a white ESTATE MANAGER.
The Dark Amber is as good as you’ll get this year. Take a sniff of that. Robin smells the crumbled leaf. A black servant brings a of tea - pot and three cups - and sets it down beside Dia
This one’s Milima Estate. More subtle fragrance, but it hasn’t got the depth. Robin smells the second type.
What do you drink?
Oh, I drink Nairobi Chai. But it’s too black for the home market. The Estate Manager crosses to the teapot beside Diana. He smells the tea in the pot, and pours.
We don’t usually get wives on these buying trips, Mrs Cavendish.
It’s Robin's business. I want to know about it.
Secret of a happy marriage, eh? Never let hubby out of your sight. Diana blinks at this. The Estate Manager is quite unaware his crassness. He shows Robin the tea in the cup.
You see the golden colour of the liquor? That’s top grade. Top price. Pure blonde.
Gentlemen prefer blondes.
Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 11A.
I’m sorry? To Robin’s amusement, Diana answers with a perfectly stra face -
Diamonds are a girl’s best friend.
Robin and Diana driving back to Nairobi in their Landrove They sing as they go.
(singing) Time rolls on and youth is gone And you can’t straighten up when you bend -
(singing) But stiff back or stiff knees -
(singing) You stand straight at Tiff’ny’s!
(singing) Diamonds are a girl’s best friend! WIDE - The Landrover drives on as night descends.
I’ve got news.
Oh?
It's a frightful bore. I shall never be able to have fun again. He throws a quick glance at her, worried.
Tell me.

I’m going to have a baby. Robin slams on the brakes.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 11B. WIDE - The car has come to a stop by the side of the road it curves round an escarpment. Beyond, the vast expanse o Africa. IN THE CAR - Robin sits motionless for a moment. Then he turns to Diana, his face radiating happiness.
Somebody's pleased.
Yes.
Very pleased?
Best news I’ve had since I proposed and you said yes.
You didn’t propose.
Didn't I?
You said you had to get married before going out to Africa or you'd go native.
But you did say yes, didn’t you?
Apparently I did.
17 18 19 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 12.

A portable record player on the Landrover is playing a scratchy record: the song is ‘True Love’ from ‘High Socie Robin has Diana in his arms, and they’re dancing, alone o the high ridge, with the great view stretching out below in the moonlight.
Sun-tanned Wind-blown Honeymooners at last alone Oh, how lucky we are! Robin and Diana are dancing slowly, smiling at each other Robin knows the words and anticipates the sung lines -
I give to you -
I give to you -
And you give to me -
And you give to me -
True love -
True love, true love So on and on It’ll always be
20 21 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 13.

The wide shaded terrace of a grand colonial building. Katherine Baring and Mary Dawnay dozing in the shade. Dia reading a novel. She’s now very pregnant. Governor EVELYN BARING comes out and stands on the terrac looking towards a distant tennis game.
Robin thrashing Colin again? His wife MOLLY BARING appears behind him.
Come on. We’ll be late. They go. The thwack of tennis balls. Diana looks up to glimpse the distant game.
Robin is playing tennis with Colin Campbell. He’s losing. Colin serves. Robin’s return hits the net.
Game! He throws his racket high into the air, whooping with triumph.
Hell of a serve, Col. I never knew you were that good.
First game I’ve had off you in my life. How about one more?
No. I’11 quit while I’m still standing. They leave the court.
God, that feels good! So this is what it’s been like to be you all these years.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 14.

Enjoy it while it lasts, old chum. They come in sight of the lawn by the terrace, and burst into laughter. Katherine Baring and Mary Dawnay are attempting the latest craze - the hula hoop. Mary is good, swinging with her hips, making the hoop spi A small crowd of friends look on and applaud. Black servants grin from the terrace. Katherine is not so good. She steps out of her hoop as Robin and Colin join them.
God, I’m useless.
(swinging away) It’s all in the hips. Robin takes the dropped hoop and steps into it. Diana loo on, smiling.
Robin’1l be a natural. You see. Robin spins the hoop, starts swinging his hips, but he can’t get the knack.
Harder than it looks.
Just imagine you’re jiving. Robin tries again. Diana looks on, smiling, one hand on h bump. Robin staggers slightly as he swings his hips. The hoop drops to the ground again.
Too much tennis. He turns to Diana. She’s not smiling any more: watching him, puzzled. He grins, moves towards her, gives his body shake as if to wake it up.
I need a drink. Colin has picked up the abandoned hoop and is spinning it with great success.
I’ve got it. It’s easy! Look at this! Robin! I’m doing it!  Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 15. Robin turns to look, smiling. He feels his left arm with his right hand.
You all right, darling?
Yes, fine. So what’s the plan?
I’ve asked Thomas to run me home. Don’s coming round to prod me.
(feeling his arm) Maybe he should give me a prod while he’s at it.
Are you sure you’re all right?
I think it’s got to me, watching you and your bump. Makes my joints ache.
I‘1l do my own aching, thank you very much. He kisses her.
you get on home. I’ve got a meeting first thing. I’1l bunk here.

A plainly-furnished ADC’s bedroom. Robin sits on the bed pyjamas, feeling one arm. Sweat on his brow. He gets up and goes out into the passage. Knocks on a doo Colin Campbell appears in the doorway, woken from sleep.
Sorry, Col. I’m not feeling so good.
You look ghastly.
My arm is giving me gyp. Colin suddenly sees that Robin’s in intense pain.  23 24
Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 16.
Robin lies on a hospital bed surrounded by medical staff. Dr Don McQueen is running checks. Colin Campbell looks on from behind. Robin is now shivering with fever.
Lift your right arm. Nothing.
Left arm. Nothing.
Legs. Robin tries to move his legs and can’t. It’s scary.
Can’t move. What’s happening? His voice comes out with difficulty.
Can’t - breathe -
Get ice! CRUSHED ICE is packed round Robin’s body by nurses, movin fast. Robin lies, eyes open, breathing with difficulty.

He’s losing it. We have to get him on a respirator. MOVING with Robin’s bed as it’s wheeled fast down a hospital corridor. Robin breathing in agonising wheezes. Don McQueen and Colin walking beside him.
Have to get oxygen into you somehow. Looks like we’re going to have to smash our way in.
INT. NAIROBI HOSPITAL - NIGHT 24a CLOSE SHOT - A scalpel slices into Robin’s throat. The tracheotomy in action.  25 26 27 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 17.

DIANA’S POV entering the ward - A bed with curtains round it. A large respirator beside it. The machine wheezes and clicks with a regular rhythm. The sound we've heard befor now identified. The nurse goes ahead of her and draws back the curtain. There lies Robin, on his back, with a tube coming out of his neck. The MOVING POV comes closer - goes round the bed - Robin lies utterly still but for his eyes, which strain t see. He looks just the same as ever, but for this spooky immobility.
Hello, darling. He looks back at her, unmoving.
Can I kiss him?

Yes. She bends over him, kisses him. Then she sits down by the bed. Her eyes have never left Robin's. His face twitches. His lips move: he’s trying to mouth words. Diana watches, pays close attention, begins to wor out what he’s saying.
‘Bit’ -
The air can’t reach the larynx any more. That’s why he can’t talk. Diana watches Robin’s lips: works it out.
He says, ‘Bit of a bugger.’
28 29 Breathe - Pink Revision - 28 June 2016 18.
Don McQueen stands at a chart showing a cutaway view of t body, explaining to Diana and Colin Campbell what has happened. Diana, very pregnant, sits on a chair.

You inhale the virus from droplets in the air, the same way you catch a cold. It passes into the blood stream, into the central nervous system, and attacks a group of big cells in the spinal cord. The anterior horn cells. These are the cells that control the voluntary muscle system. The result is you become like a rag doll. You can’t move anything from the neck down. You can’t even breathe for yourself. He stops. Silence, while they take it in.
How long will he be like this?
The paralysis is irreversible. A good respiration system will maintain life for a while. We're talking a matter of months. Diana takes this in in silence.
Does it affect his brain?
Not at all. Mentally he’s as alert as ever. He can move some facial muscles, as you've seen. His digestive system's unaffected. Diana looks up.
Can he feel me if I touch him?
Yes. He can still feel.

Diana sits beside Robin’s bed, one hand reached out. She’ stroking his face very slowly. He has his eyes closed.  30 31 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 19. The machine hisses and clicks beside them. The tube carrying air to his throat twitches. ON DIANA - She’s not weeping. She’s just hurting so deepl she can hardly move.
The Governor, Evelyn Baring, and Colin Campbell, look on silence as Molly Baring sits with Diana, holding her hand
Tell me what we can do. Diana can’t answer.
Do you want to go home?
After the baby’s born.
What about Robin?
Him too.
You do know? She looks round to her husband to say what she can’t brin herself to say.
I’ve seen enough people paralysed by polio before. The mercy of it is, they don’t last long. Diana nods.
It’s no kind of life. Diana nods. Colin looks down. He can hardly bear this.

ON DIANA - Her head on a pillow, her eyes closed. She tur her head from side to side. Her face creases with pain. N sound. She seems to be asleep, perhaps having a bad dream Then her suffering intensifies. She bangs her head from side to side, her mouth opens in a silent scream, sweat glistens on her brow. It must be a hideous nightmare.  32 33 34 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 20. Then she jerks up, her eyes open, the pain unbearable. It bursts from her in a scream of agony.

Aaa-aaah! WIDE - Full sound. We now see we’re in a maternity ward i Nairobi. MIDWIVES and NURSES clustered round the bed. A pool of light on the lower part of the bed, obscured by their busy activity. A baby is being born.

MOVING POV tracking down the bright corridor as before, past the screens swaying in the breeze. Through doors and outer rooms. The MOVING POV enters Robin’s room and approaches his bed Robin gazes AT CAMERA. Diana holds the TINY BABY for him to see. The baby gazes back just as gravely at Robin. ON ROBIN - He gazes at the baby for a moment longer. Then he closes his eyes. Diana holds the baby against Robin’s unmoving cheek. A ki of contact for a moment. Then she takes him away. She watches Robin in silence. Kisses her baby’s cheek. No movement from Robin. His eyes stay closed. The respirator fills the silence with its hissing and clickin

A TRANSPORT PLANE has just landed. The cargo doors are op and a tricky unloading operation is under way. Robin Cavendish is being hoisted out of the plane, strapped to stretcher. A big battery powered respirator is being unloaded alongside him. An ambulance waits to receive him Medics, RAF personnel and ground crew are gathered round.

Easy now. Take it slowly. Keep some slack in the tube. That’s more like it. Down you come. They get the stretcher onto the tarmac. Now the respirato has to be man-handled into the ambulance.  35 36 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 21.

(to Robin) Disconnecting you for a moment. ON ROBIN - The sound of the respirator ceases. He is no longer breathing. He takes it calmly, but for us the wait is unnerving. We hear the grunts and scrapes as the big respirator is heaved into the ambulance, and the sounds o wires being clipped back into place. Then Robin’s stretcher is on the move, into the ambulance The respirator starts up. The tube is replaced in his throat. Robin breathes again. His eyes close.
Diana sits waiting with TID, her former nanny, called out retirement to help. A proud and capable woman. The pram stands between them. A young Pakistani doctor, DR KHAN, approaches.
Mrs Cavendish?
Yes.
I’m really sorry. This isn’t a good time. We’ve had to medicate your husband. Perhaps you could come back tomorrow.
I don’t mind if he’s asleep. I'd just like to see him.
I don’t think it’s a good idea.
I’m sorry. I don’t understand. The doctor hesitates.
You know, with this sort of thing the morale can drop pretty low at times. Your husband is going through a temporary depression.  37 38 39 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 22.
I'd still like to see him.
I’m so sorry. He doesn’t want to see you. Diana stares: shocked.

Robin lies in his hospital bed, linked to his respirator. It hisses and clicks as it pumps away. SLOW MOVE IN on Robin. He lies with his eyes open, lookin up at nothing, tears seeping down his cheeks.
Diana is on her way out of the hospital, with her baby in pram, accompanied by Tid.
I’ll be able to manage from now on, Tid. It’s not fair to ask you to do this.
I don’t see why not. I looked after you when you were a baby, didn’t I?
The thing is, we’re not very well off, I’m afraid. We’ve got some savings, but there’s not a lot coming in.
Don’t you worry about that. Your family’s my family, really. It’s nice to be back.

TRACK into the ward. Six beds, each one surrounded by medical apparatus, each one linked to a respirator, each one hissing and clicking as it pumps away. This sound, a syncopated rhythm of overlapping beats, fills the air. Diana’s brothers, Bloggs and David, sit on either side of Robin’s bed. Robin is laboriously mouthing words. Bloggs struggling to understand.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 23.
Sorry. I’m not being very clever here. Robin tries again. He’s mouthing three words. Bloggs catches the lips-together form of an M.
Mmm. ‘Mum’?
Why would he say ‘mum’?
Maybe he wants to see his mum.
(watching Robin) Ma? Moo? Me? Robin mouths ‘Yes’.
‘Me.’ Robin goes back to mouthing his three words.
Eh. Me. Aye.
Eh. ‘Get’ - is the first word “get'?
Or ‘let’?
‘Let - me - lie’?
He is lying. Sorry, Robin. You must think we’re awful chumps. Robin mouths again. David suddenly gets it.
‘Let me die.’ Robin closes his eyes, sinks back exhausted.
Let me die.
Well, that’s pretty bloody final, I must say.  40 Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 24.
Diana walks through Oxford lanes with her brothers Bloggs and David. Students rattle past on bikes, dodging them as they go. Diana is putting on a good face, refusing to be sorry for herself.
Diana, darling. How can we help?
Oh, I shall manage.
How are you off for money?
I’ve got my share of what Mother left us. That'll keep us going for a while.
Talking to Robin was rather like one of those ghastly party games where you don’t know the rules.
It was clever of you to get him to say anything at all. Bloggs comes to a stop.
What he said was, ‘Let me die’. Diana meets Bloggs’s eyes. Giving nothing away.
Well, we can’t, can we? As they resume their progress down the lane -
Do you mean we can’t even think such a thing, or we don’t know how to do it?
Both, I suppose.
Makes no odds, really. I had a sort of a word with the Consultant. He wouldn't hear of it.  4l Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 25.
Not what they do.
He said it’s not a good way to go. Several minutes of agony.
No. I don’t want that.
Of course not.
On the other hand, you have a life too.
You are allowed to think of yourself.
Diana sits by Robin’s bed with her baby on her lap. Robin lies with his eyes open, but he’s not looking at either o them. The baby is fascinated by the rise and fall of the respirator.

He couldn’t go on having no name. I decided to call him Jonathan. I hope that’s all right. No response from Robin. Diana watches him in silence. DR ENTWISTLE now joins them accompanied by his entourage, which includes Dr Khan. He checks his notes. Speaks in professionally cheerful tones.
Well, Mrs Cavendish. We do have some progress to report.
Progress?
We're learning to swallow again.
We are?
It’s more significant than it sounds. (MORE )
42 Breathe - Green Revision - 8 July 2016 26.

At present we have an inflated cuff round our tracheotomy tube, to stop food or drink going down our windpipe. If we can swallow again, the cuff can be removed, and air can get to the larynx. Then we’ll be able to talk again. Diana takes this in.
Might there be other progress too?
This is about as good as it’s going to get, I’m afraid. (to Robin) How are we this morning? Robin stares back at him in silence.
We wish we were dead. A twitch in Robin’s face. Was it a ghost of a smile?

(not listening) Good, good. Dr Entwistle moves on. He can be heard at the next bed, speaking breezily to another paralysed patient, PADDY. Paddy, a 40-year-old ex-soldier, is on a respirator like Robin.
Good morning to you, Paddy. Ticking along as usual, I see.

Diana sits on a rug in this open quadrangle, an area of b grass, watching over baby Jonathan as he wriggles on his tummy beside her. Tid is pouring cups of tea for them fro Thermos flask. Diana’s face is turned away from us. Baby Jonathan manages a short burst of crawling.
There’s a young lad who'll be on the move before we know it. Diana turns to her. Now we see the strain on her face.  Breathe - Blue Revision - 26 June 2016 27.
He never looks at him, Tid. He can’t bear even to look at him.
You don’t know that.
Yes, I do. I know everything he’s thinking. Each time I go there I hope he’1l have changed. But he can’t bear to look at his own son.
I loved my home, but when I left, I couldn’t turn and look back. I loved it too much.
Oh, Tid. The baby makes gurgling noises.
There. Listen to him. He’ll be talking soon.
